content: are there any surveys (or even just nice results) concerning the relations between different test categories? along the lines of how simplices sit nicely inside trees, giving a way of viewing simplicial sets as dendroidal sets. more generally, i was hoping for some big diagram that explains how e.g. globular, cubical, simplicial, dendroidal, Theta, etc. sets all relate to each other, when we have functors between them, how/when/if they're equivalent, and so on
Sounds like a nice idea! I don't know such a survey, but there seem to be lots of results.
While not on test categories in general, there is this paper on the essential subtoposes (aka levels) of cubical and simplicial sets.
Ieke Moerdijk also has some notes on trees which has some stuff on the relationship between simplicial sets and dendroidal sets
it’s the kind of thing i’d love to write, but unfortunately i only really know about simplicial and globular things!
but if i can find enough references then it would be a fun task to try to piece them all together into a big picture
I'd also be very happy to collaborate on such a survey!

have the people working on model-independent (∞,1)(\infty,1)(∞,1)-category theory got some results in this direction maybe? if there are explicit arguments for why say globular sets and cubical sets both have some notion of "quasi-category" and why these are both equivalent, that would be really nice

I guess the fact that both globular sets and cubical sets are presheaves on generalized Reedy categories might be relevant... very roughly speaking, generalized Reedy categories are categories of shapes where each shape has a "dimension" 0, 1, 2, 3, ...

Not really an answer, but I wondering something a bit bigger, some years ago: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/24997/is-there-an-interesting-definition-of-a-category-of-test-categories with no real conclusion.
